G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, the amount in controversy—approximately $3,300 in special damages to date, plus pain and suffering and other damages—is within the civil jurisdiction of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 212, § 3, the amount in controversy—approximately $3,300 in special damages to date, plus pain and suffering and other damages—is within the civil jurisdiction of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the events and occurrences giving rise to Plaintiff’s claims took place in Worcester, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Worcester Division of the District Court Department.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of real property owes all lawful visitors a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between licensees and invitees and replacing it with a unified standard of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors. Although the excerpt provided is from a concurrence discussing trespassers, the majority at 363 Mass. 707–08 expressly states that an occupier owes all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable person in maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition under all the circumstances. Thus the case squarely supports the proposition as to lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707\.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the duty owed by the occupier of land should no longer depend on the common law status of the injured party as either an invitee or licensee. The proper test is whether, in the management of his property, the occupier has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others… We conclude that an occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.”

*Dipasquale v. Gow*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 62.proposition: This duty of reasonable care extends to the maintenance of exterior areas appurtenant to the property, including sidewalks, walkways, and means of ingress and egress that tenants and their invitees may reasonably be expected to use.
*Dipasquale v. Gow*, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 62.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a lengthy criminal conspiracy decision dealing with indictments, fragmentation of conspiracy counts, severance, and evidentiary/sentencing issues. It does not concern landlord-tenant duties, premises liability, or maintenance of exterior areas such as sidewalks or ingress/egress. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition about a landlord’s duty of reasonable care for exterior appurtenant areas.

*Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 3.raw_text: *Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 348 Mass. 198, 202 (1964)
*Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 3.proposition: This duty of reasonable care extends to the maintenance of exterior areas appurtenant to the property, including sidewalks, walkways, and means of ingress and egress that tenants and their invitees may reasonably be expected to use.
*Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 3.case_name: Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody
*Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the duty of reasonable care owed by a store to its invitees and analyzes negligence in placing and using a ramp in the exterior access roadway and sidewalk area, but it does not expressly frame this as a rule about a landlord’s or possessor’s duty to maintain all exterior appurtenant areas such as sidewalks and means of ingress/egress. The case is focused on the specific negligent conduct (placement of the ramp and bundle boys’ behavior) rather than articulating a broader doctrinal statement that the duty of reasonable care generally extends to all exterior appurtenant areas used by tenants and invitees. Thus it is consistent with, but does not clearly establish, the proposition as a general rule.
*Luz v. Stop & Shop, Inc. of Peabody*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “As to any invitee Stop & Shop owed the duty of ordinary care and diligence to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition. … The jury could reasonably find that the placement of the ramp, coupled with the behavior of the bundle boys, constituted negligence.” (348 Mass. at 203–204).

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.proposition: A landlord who retains control over common areas, such as walkways used by multiple tenants and their guests, is obligated to exercise reasonable care to keep such areas in a condition reasonably safe for their intended use.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses landlord duties for common areas under their control. It explains that, even under the traditional common-law regime, a landlord owed a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common passageways for tenants and their visitors, and it cites prior Massachusetts cases (Lindsey and King) that expressly recognize this duty. Although Young v. Garwacki extends negligence liability into demised premises, its discussion of existing law on common areas directly supports the stated proposition.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.relevant_excerpt: “The landlord ‘was under a separate and limited duty toward each tenant and that tenant’s visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas in a condition not less safe than they were, or appeared to be in, at the time of the letting to the particular tenant.’ King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977). Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 81-82 (1977). … In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control…”

*Cataruzza v. Western Mass. Elec. Co.*,.raw_text: *Cataruzza v. Western Mass. Elec. Co.*, 412 Mass. 445, 448 (1992)
*Cataruzza v. Western Mass. Elec. Co.*,.proposition: A landlord who retains control over common areas, such as walkways used by multiple tenants and their guests, is obligated to exercise reasonable care to keep such areas in a condition reasonably safe for their intended use.
*Cataruzza v. Western Mass. Elec. Co.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns insurance contract interpretation and duplicate recovery under underinsured motorist and medical payments coverages. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, control of common areas, or duties regarding walkways or other common spaces. Therefore, it does not provide any authority for the proposition about a landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition.
*Cataruzza v. Western Mass. Elec. Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: Nothing in the provided opinion text addresses landlord obligations or control over common areas; the discussion is limited to insurance policy language, duplicate payments, and statutory underinsured motorist provisions.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landowners to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances in maintaining their property, including addressing hazards created by snow and ice.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and explicitly replaces it with a general premises-liability duty of reasonable care for all hazards arising from snow and ice. The court states that property owners owe lawful visitors the same obligation of reasonable care for snow and ice as for any other hazard, which matches the proposition that Massachusetts law requires landowners to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances in maintaining property, including snow and ice hazards.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ ... If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice ... the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger."

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landowners to act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances in maintaining their property, including addressing hazards created by snow and ice.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sullivan v. Brookline concerns disability retirement, reinstatement standards, and mandatory retraining for long‑term retirees under G.L. c. 32, § 8(2) and G.L. c. 31, § 39. It does not address premises liability, duties of landowners, or hazards from snow and ice. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about a landowner’s duty to act reasonably in maintaining property, including snow and ice conditions.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353,.relevant_excerpt: A requirement of retraining prior to reinstatement to full duty is consistent with the language and the purposes of St. 1996, c. 306, and G. L. c. 31, § 39. Imposing retraining prior to reinstatement reduces the costs associated with rehiring former retirees and contributes to the efficiency of the retirement system.

*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77, 80.proposition: Even apart from actual notice, the recurring melt‑and‑refreeze condition following a significant snowstorm created a foreseeable risk that the shoveled path would become dangerously icy, such that a reasonable property owner would have taken steps to inspect and treat the area.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77, 80.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects liability for a natural accumulation of snow and ice and affirms summary judgment for the landowners, emphasizing that mere slipping on naturally accumulated ice does not show negligence. It does not state that recurring melt‑and‑refreeze after a storm makes it foreseeable and thus requires inspection and treatment; instead, it stresses that landowners are not insurers and that in this case there was no evidence of a defective or altered condition beyond natural accumulation. The proposition overstates the duty recognized in this case.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77, 80.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs wrongly conclude, however, that the defendants breached this duty by failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice on their property. The duty of reasonable care ‘does not make landowners and occupiers insurers of their property nor does it impose unreasonable maintenance burdens.’… There is no evidence in this case which would allow a jury to find that the defendants failed to exercise reasonable care in the circumstances and created a defective condition on their property.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care that a reasonable property owner and landlord would employ in similar circumstances, in violation of her common‑law duty of reasonable care.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses duty and foreseeability, not breach. The court holds that Kask, as a homeowner/landlord figure, owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms given Jason’s known history, and reverses summary judgment so a jury can decide whether she exercised reasonable care. It does not hold that her conduct in fact fell below the standard of care; instead, it explicitly reserves that determination for the jury, so it cannot be cited as authority that her conduct violated the common‑law standard of care.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

*Dubois v. Debreuil*, 304 Mass. 229, 231.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care that a reasonable property owner and landlord would employ in similar circumstances, in violation of her common‑law duty of reasonable care.
*Dubois v. Debreuil*, 304 Mass. 229, 231.case_name: Springfield Safe Deposit & Trust Co. v. Friele
*Dubois v. Debreuil*, 304 Mass. 229, 231.support_reasoning: The case concerns the interpretation and administration of a testamentary trust and whether surplus income may be distributed to a residuary beneficiary before termination of annuities. It does not involve premises liability, landlord‑tenant duties, or any standard of care for property owners. Accordingly, it provides no authority on whether a defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care owed by a reasonable property owner or landlord.
*Dubois v. Debreuil*, 304 Mass. 229, 231.relevant_excerpt: “In our opinion the same considerations that prompted the court in Broadway National Bank v. Adams, and in Claflin v. Claflin to decline to follow the English rule should prompt us to decline to follow the rule laid down in Harbin v. Masterman… Although in the case at bar this surplus income will eventually become a part of the residue, it does not follow that it should be distributed at this time.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: The hazardous condition of the ice‑covered shoveled path was a direct and substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s fall and resultant injuries.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns causation from a hazardous ice‑covered shoveled path in a slip‑and‑fall scenario, but this case (and specifically this dissent) concerns proximate cause in a campus security/rape context. The opinion text provided does not involve ice, a shoveled path, or any discussion of such a hazardous condition being a direct and substantial factor in causing a fall. Instead, it addresses whether negligent security measures proximately caused a criminal assault, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any comparative negligence by Plaintiff, which is denied, would not bar recovery but would merely reduce damages in proportion to any such fault.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85, 85K.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover compensatory damages from Defendant for past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and all other damages recoverable under Massachusetts law.

*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.proposition: Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recover compensatory damages from Defendant for past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and all other damages recoverable under Massachusetts law.
*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Dobos v. Driscoll deals with liability, immunity, supervisory negligence, and standards under § 1983 and the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act. It does not address the specific categories or scope of compensatory damages recoverable by a plaintiff (such as past and future medical expenses, lost wages, or pain and suffering) under Massachusetts law. The opinion assumes the existence of damages but does not discuss or establish any rule regarding what types of damages are recoverable; thus it does not support the proposition as cited.

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is timely under the three‑year statute of limitations for tort actions.

*White v. Peabody Constr. Co.*, 386 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is timely under the three‑year statute of limitations for tort actions.
*White v. Peabody Constr. Co.*, 386 Mass.case_name: White v. Peabody Construction Co., Inc.
*White v. Peabody Constr. Co.*, 386 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the three‑year statute of limitations for tort actions (G.L. c. 260, § 2B) to the plaintiffs’ negligence claims, but holds that the claims are untimely, not timely. The court concludes the causes of action accrued in 1975 when the leaks began and that the limitations period expired in 1978, while the complaint was filed in 1980. Thus the case stands as authority for the claims being time‑barred under the three‑year statute, the opposite of the proposition cited.
*White v. Peabody Constr. Co.*, 386 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiffs’ causes of action in negligence accrued in 1975 (when they moved into their apartments), their action, brought in 1980, is barred by G. L. c. 260, § 2B. … The plaintiffs here knew they were injured in 1975. … In the circumstances of the case before us, the three-year limitations period began to run in 1975 and expired in 1978, well before the plaintiffs’ complaint was filed in 1980.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
